channel.title: CNN.com - RSS Channel - Health
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright (c) 2017 Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

item.title: Stopping the opioid crisis in the womb
item.description: Dr. Craig Towers at The University of Tennessee Medical Center is shattering the medical belief that detoxing during pregnancy could lead to the death of the fetus. CNN follows one woman's journey to get clean for her baby.

item.title: Getting clean while pregnant
item.description: Dr. Craig Towers at The University of Tennessee Medical Center is working to change the policy on whether women addicted to opiates can detox during pregnancy.

item.title: Skyrocketing rate of babies going through opioid withdrawal
item.description: The high-pitched, inconsolable screams of babies born dependent on heroin and other opiates echo across the otherwise quiet facility.

item.title: In America's drug death capital, heroin is scarring the next generation
item.description: Sara Murray tends to two dozen babies in the neonatal therapeutic unit at Cabell Huntington Hospital. They shake. They vomit. Their inconsolable, high-pitched screams pierce the air. The symptoms can last for hours, days or months.

item.title: A generation of heroin orphans
item.description: It was bedtime in the Flynn household but the kids were wide awake, excited by the arrival of CNN reporters to their colorful, crowded Kentucky home. The entry is crammed with bunk beds on one side and, separated by a bookshelf, a makeshift den with a desk and computer on the other.

item.title: 2 governors, 2 different approaches to fight opioid crisis
item.description: Lawmakers across the country are trying various methods to combat the staggering opioid epidemic, and two states' governors are taking matters into their own hands to fight the escalating crisis.

item.title: Is pizza healthy?
item.description: Pizza is healthy. And it isn't healthy.

item.title: What about wine?
item.description: Yes, wine may protect our hearts when consumed in moderation -- defined as up to one drink per day for women, and up to two drinks per day for men, according to US dietary guidelines. Five ounces of wine is considered one drink.

item.title: FDA approves first new drug for ALS treatment in 22 years
item.description: The US Food and Drug Administration has approved the first new drug for the treatment of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or ALS, in more than two decades.

item.title: Pre-existing conditions: Pregnancy, sleep apnea could make you pay more
item.description: Millions of Americans are uncertain about their future as a new health care bill heads to the Senate.

item.title: Here's a (partial) list of all the pre-existing conditions the GOP bill may not cover
item.description: The term "pre-existing condition" is vague -- and every insurance company has its own lists of "declinable" or "uninsurable."

item.title: Rape and domestic violence could be pre-existing conditions
item.description: Jody Neal-Post has been reading about the health care law debate with worry these days.

item.title: 'Alarming' rise in children hospitalized with suicidal thoughts or actions
item.description: The percentage of younger children and teens hospitalized for suicidal thoughts or actions in the United States doubled over nearly a decade, according to new research that will be presented Sunday at the 2017 Pediatric Academic Societies Meeting.

item.title: Health care bill 'shameful,' 'harmful,' medical groups say
item.description: Republicans may be jubilant that revamped health care legislation finally passed the House on Thursday, but many of the professional associations that represent America's health care workers are clearly unhappy.

item.title: Yellow fever fears prompt monkey killings in Brazil
item.description: In rural Brazil, an outbreak of yellow fever that began in December is considered the largest in 14 years.

item.title: Aunt Jemima frozen pancakes, waffles and French toast recalled
item.description: A New Jersey food company is recalling Aunt Jemima frozen pancakes, frozen waffles and frozen French toast over fears of listeria contamination.

item.title: All your questions about fidget spinners, answered
item.description: If you know a middle school kid, or a parent or teacher of one, chances are you've seen the simple little colorful device that's driving them all crazy lately.

item.title: Ohio teacher fired for dragging student
item.description: An Ohio teacher was fired this week after she was photographed dragging a young student by the arm down a school hallway.

item.title: How hotel soap can save lives
item.description: The Eco-Soap Bank recycles discarded bars of soap from hotels in Cambodia and distributes it to people in need--preventing disease and creating jobs.

item.title: Babies' speech delays could be linked to mobile devices
item.description: Anyone raising a child today has likely fretted about screen time and wondered about the impact of devices on our kids. Does the technology affect their brains? Does it limit their social development? Could it harm them emotionally? Could it delay when they start talking?

item.title: A not-so-sweet new way to test for pee in pools
4-year-old uses 'the Force' to fight cancer
item.description: Callan Kott's parents knew that something was wrong with their child when the 3-year-old looked pale and suddenly stopped singing karaoke at a Christmas party in December 2015. The New Orleans boy was usually the "life of the party" who loved to dance.

item.title: The pros and cons of working into your 90s
item.description: Society often suggests that we should slow down in later life. With retirement, we can reflect on what we have achieved, get out to see the world and spend time with family.

item.title: 16 US children hospitalized with gunshot wounds each day, study says
Teacher rocks prom night with special needs students
item.description: The excitement in the images is palpable. There are beautiful gowns, tuxedos and camera flashes. And at the center of it all, 13 special education students kicking off their prom night.

item.title: She's graduating college even before she finishes high school
item.description: Raven Osborne started taking college courses at Purdue University since she was a freshman. And she just kept going and going

item.title: Twin sisters use style to break barriers for the deaf
item.description: Hermon and Heroda Berhane have been deaf since childhood. Now the twin sisters are using their unique style to encourage others to embrace disabilities.

item.title: Experts warn of increase in tick-borne Powassan virus
The foods converting Germans to vegans
item.description: When thinking of a typically German meal, two particular items probably spring to mind: bratwurst sausage and a tender schnitzel.

item.title: Actress and writer Jeannie Gaffigan has surgery for brain tumor
item.description: Actress and writer Jeannie Gaffigan, wife of comedian Jim Gaffigan, is recovering after emergency surgery to remove a tumor from her brain stem.
